prop.name: label
prop.value: Prepare the Organization (PO)

part.name: overview
part.p: Organizations should ensure that their people, processes, and technology are prepared to perform secure software development at the organization level. Many organizations will find some PO practices to also be applicable to subsets of their secure software development, like individual development groups or projects.

control.title: Define Security Requirements for Software Development

prop.name: label
prop.value: Define Security Requirements for Software Development (PO.1)

part.name: statement
part.p: Ensure that security requirements for software development are known at all times so that they can be taken into account throughout the SDLC and duplication of effort can be minimized because the requirements information can be collected once and shared. This includes requirements from internal sources (e.g., the organization’s policies, business objectives, and risk management strategy) and external sources (e.g., applicable laws and regulations).

link.text: Planning the Implementation and Deployment of Secure Development Practices

part.name: statement
part.p: Identify and document all security requirements for the organization’s software development infrastructures and processes, and maintain the requirements over time.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Define policies for securing software development infrastructures and their components, including development endpoints, throughout the SDLC and maintaining that security.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Define policies for securing software development processes throughout the SDLC and maintaining that security, including for open-source and other third-party software components utilized by software being developed.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Review and update security requirements at least annually, or sooner if there are new requirements from internal or external sources, or a major security incident targeting software development infrastructure has occurred.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Educate affected individuals on impending changes to requirements.

link.text: SC.1-1, SC.2, PD.1-1, PD.1-2, PD.1-3, PD.2-2, SI, PA, CS, AA, LO, EE
PC1-A, PC1-B, PC2-A, PC3-A, SR1-A, SR1-B, SR2-B, SA1-B, IR1-A

part.name: statement
part.p: Identify and document all security requirements for organization-developed software to meet, and maintain the requirements over time.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Define policies that specify risk-based software architecture and design requirements, such as making code modular to facilitate code reuse and updates; isolating security components from other components during execution; avoiding undocumented commands and settings; and providing features that will aid software acquirers with the secure deployment, operation, and maintenance of the software.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Define policies that specify the security requirements for the organization’s software, and verify compliance at key points in the SDLC (e.g., classes of software flaws verified by gates, responses to vulnerabilities discovered in released software).

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Analyze the risk of applicable technology stacks (e.g., languages, environments, deployment models), and recommend or require the use of stacks that will reduce risk compared to others.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Define policies that specify what needs to be archived for each software release (e.g., code, package files, third-party libraries, documentation, data inventory) and how long it needs to be retained based on the SDLC model, software end-of-life, and other factors.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 5:
part.p: Ensure that policies cover the entire software life cycle, including notifying users of the impending end of software support and the date of software end-of-life.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 6:
part.p: Review all security requirements at least annually, or sooner if there are new requirements from internal or external sources, a major vulnerability is discovered in released software, or a major security incident targeting organization-developed software has occurred.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 7:
part.p: Establish and follow processes for handling requirement exception requests, including periodic reviews of all approved exceptions.

link.text: Tasks Requiring the Help of Security Experts 8
Manage Security Risk Inherent in the Use of Third-Party Components

part.name: statement
part.p: Communicate requirements to all third parties who will provide commercial software components to the organization for reuse by the organization’s own software. .Formerly PW.3.1

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Define a core set of security requirements for software components, and include it in acquisition documents, software contracts, and other agreements with third parties.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Define security-related criteria for selecting software; the criteria can include the third party’s vulnerability disclosure program and product security incident response capabilities or the third party’s adherence to organization-defined practices.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Require third parties to attest that their software complies with the organization’s security requirements.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Require third parties to provide provenance data and integrity verification mechanisms for all components of their software.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 5:
part.p: Establish and follow processes to address risk when there are security requirements that third-party software components to be acquired do not meet; this should include periodic reviews of all approved exceptions to requirements.

prop.name: label
prop.value: Implement Roles and Responsibilities (PO.2)

part.name: statement
part.p: Ensure that everyone inside and outside of the organization involved in the SDLC is prepared to perform their SDLC-related roles and responsibilities throughout the SDLC.

part.name: statement
part.p: Create new roles and alter responsibilities for existing roles as needed to encompass all parts of the SDLC. Periodically review and maintain the defined roles and responsibilities, updating them as needed.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Define SDLC-related roles and responsibilities for all members of the software development team.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Integrate the security roles into the software development team.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Define roles and responsibilities for cybersecurity staff, security champions, project managers and leads, senior management, software developers, software testers, software assurance leads and staff, product owners, operations and platform engineers, and others involved in the SDLC.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Conduct an annual review of all roles and responsibilities.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 5:
part.p: Educate affected individuals on impending changes to roles and responsibilities, and confirm that the individuals understand the changes and agree to follow them.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 6:
part.p: Implement and use tools and processes to promote communication and engagement among individuals with SDLC-related roles and responsibilities, such as creating messaging channels for team discussions.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 7:
part.p: Designate a group of individuals or a team as the code owner for each project.

link.text: Operational Security Tasks 14, 15; Tasks Requiring the Help of Security Experts 1
Planning the Implementation and Deployment of Secure Development Practices

part.name: statement
part.p: Provide role-based training for all personnel with responsibilities that contribute to secure development. Periodically review personnel proficiency and role-based training, and update the training as needed.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Document the desired outcomes of training for each role.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Define the type of training or curriculum required to achieve the desired outcome for each role.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Create a training plan for each role.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Acquire or create training for each role; acquired training may need to be customized for the organization.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 5:
part.p: Measure outcome performance to identify areas where changes to training may be beneficial.

part.name: statement
part.p: Obtain upper management or authorizing official commitment to secure development, and convey that commitment to all with development-related roles and responsibilities.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Appoint a single leader or leadership team to be responsible for the entire secure software development process, including being accountable for releasing software to production and delegating responsibilities as appropriate.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Increase authorizing officials’ awareness of the risks of developing software without integrating security throughout the development life cycle and the risk mitigation provided by secure development practices.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Assist upper management in incorporating secure development support into their communications with personnel with development-related roles and responsibilities.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Educate all personnel with development-related roles and responsibilities on upper management’s commitment to secure development and the importance of secure development to the organization.

prop.name: label
prop.value: Implement Supporting Toolchains (PO.3)

part.name: statement
part.p: Use automation to reduce human effort and improve the accuracy, reproducibility, usability, and comprehensiveness of security practices throughout the SDLC, as well as provide a way to document and demonstrate the use of these practices. Toolchains and tools may be used at different levels of the organization, such as organization-wide or project-specific, and may address a particular part of the SDLC, like a build pipeline.

link.text: Tasks Requiring the Help of Security Experts 9

part.name: statement
part.p: Specify which tools or tool types must or should be included in each toolchain to mitigate identified risks, as well as how the toolchain components are to be integrated with each other.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Define categories of toolchains, and specify the mandatory tools or tool types to be used for each category.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Identify security tools to integrate into the developer toolchain.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Define what information is to be passed between tools and what data formats are to be used.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Evaluate tools’ signing capabilities to create immutable records/logs for auditability within the toolchain.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 5:
part.p: Use automated technology for toolchain management and orchestration.

link.text: Securing Build Pipelines—Verification, Automation, Controlled Environments, Secure Authentication/Access; Securing Artefacts—Verification, Automation, Controlled Environments, Encryption; Securing Deployments—Verification, Automation
Tasks Requiring the Help of Security Experts 9
Use Current Compiler and Toolchain Versions and Secure Compiler Options

part.name: statement
part.p: Follow recommended security practices to deploy, operate, and maintain tools and toolchains.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Evaluate, select, and acquire tools, and assess the security of each tool.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Integrate tools with other tools and existing software development processes and workflows.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Use code-based configuration for toolchains (e.g., pipelines-as-code, toolchains-as-code).

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Implement the technologies and processes needed for reproducible builds.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 5:
part.p: Update, upgrade, or replace tools as needed to address tool vulnerabilities or add new tool capabilities.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 6:
part.p: Continuously monitor tools and tool logs for potential operational and security issues, including policy violations and anomalous behavior.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 7:
part.p: Regularly verify the integrity and check the provenance of each tool to identify potential problems.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 8:
part.p: See PW.6 regarding compiler, interpreter, and build tools.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 9:
part.p: See PO.5 regarding implementing and maintaining secure environments.

link.text: Securing Build Pipelines—Verification, Automation, Controlled Environments; Securing Artefacts—Verification
Tasks Requiring the Help of Security Experts 9

part.name: statement
part.p: Configure tools to generate artifacts of their support of secure software development practices as defined by the organization.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Use existing tooling (e.g., workflow tracking, issue tracking, value stream mapping) to create an audit trail of the secure development-related actions that are performed for continuous improvement purposes.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Determine how often the collected information should be audited, and implement the necessary processes.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Establish and enforce security and retention policies for artifact data.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Assign responsibility for creating any needed artifacts that tools cannot generate.

control.title: Define and Use Criteria for Software Security Checks

prop.name: label
prop.value: Define and Use Criteria for Software Security Checks (PO.4)

part.name: statement
part.p: Help ensure that the software resulting from the SDLC meets the organization’s expectations by defining and using criteria for checking the software’s security during development.

part.name: statement
part.p: Define criteria for software security checks and track throughout the SDLC.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Ensure that the criteria adequately indicate how effectively security risk is being managed.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Define key performance indicators (KPIs), key risk indicators (KRIs), vulnerability severity scores, and other measures for software security.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Add software security criteria to existing checks (e.g., the Definition of Done in agile SDLC methodologies).

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Review the artifacts generated as part of the software development workflow system to determine if they meet the criteria.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 5:
part.p: Record security check approvals, rejections, and exception requests as part of the workflow and tracking system.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 6:
part.p: Analyze collected data in the context of the security successes and failures of each development project, and use the results to improve the SDLC.

part.name: statement
part.p: Implement processes, mechanisms, etc. to gather and safeguard the necessary information in support of the criteria.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Use the toolchain to automatically gather information that informs security decision-making.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Deploy additional tools if needed to support the generation and collection of information supporting the criteria.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Automate decision-making processes utilizing the criteria, and periodically review these processes.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Only allow authorized personnel to access the gathered information, and prevent any alteration or deletion of the information.

control.title: Implement and Maintain Secure Environments for Software Development

prop.name: label
prop.value: Implement and Maintain Secure Environments for Software Development (PO.5)

part.name: statement
part.p: Ensure that all components of the environments for software development are strongly protected from internal and external threats to prevent compromises of the environments or the software being developed or maintained within them. Examples of environments for software development include development, build, test, and distribution environments.

link.text: Tasks Requiring the Help of Security Experts 11

part.name: statement
part.p: Separate and protect each environment involved in software development.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Use multi-factor, risk-based authentication and conditional access for each environment.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 10:
part.p: Configure and implement measures to secure the environments’ hosting infrastructures following a zero trust architecture.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Use network segmentation and access controls to separate the environments from each other and from production environments, and to separate components from each other within each non-production environment, in order to reduce attack surfaces and attackers’ lateral movement and privilege/access escalation.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Enforce authentication and tightly restrict connections entering and exiting each software development environment, including minimizing access to the internet to only what is necessary.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Minimize direct human access to toolchain systems, such as build services. Continuously monitor and audit all access attempts and all use of privileged access.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 5:
part.p: Minimize the use of production-environment software and services from non-production environments.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 6:
part.p: Regularly log, monitor, and audit trust relationships for authorization and access between the environments and between the components within each environment.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 7:
part.p: Continuously log and monitor operations and alerts across all components of the development environment to detect, respond, and recover from attempted and actual cyber incidents.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 8:
part.p: Configure security controls and other tools involved in separating and protecting the environments to generate artifacts for their activities.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 9:
part.p: Continuously monitor all software deployed in each environment for new vulnerabilities, and respond to vulnerabilities appropriately following a risk-based approach.

link.text: PR.AC-4, PR.AC-7, PR.IP-1, PR.IP-3, PR.IP-12, PR.PT-1, PR.PT-3, DE.CM
Tasks Requiring the Help of Security Experts 11

part.name: statement
part.p: Secure and harden development endpoints (i.e., endpoints for software designers, developers, testers, builders, etc.) to perform development-related tasks using a risk-based approach.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Configure each development endpoint based on approved hardening guides, checklists, etc.; for example, enable FIPS-compliant encryption of all sensitive data at rest and in transit.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Configure each development endpoint and the development resources to provide the least functionality needed by users and services and to enforce the principle of least privilege.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Continuously monitor the security posture of all development endpoints, including monitoring and auditing all use of privileged access.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Configure security controls and other tools involved in securing and hardening development endpoints to generate artifacts for their activities.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 5:
part.p: Require multi-factor authentication for all access to development endpoints and development resources.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 6:
part.p: Provide dedicated development endpoints on non-production networks for performing all development-related tasks. Provide separate endpoints on production networks for all other tasks.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 7:
part.p: Configure each development endpoint following a zero trust architecture.

prop.name: label
prop.value: Protect Software (PS)

part.name: overview
part.p: Organizations should protect all components of the software from tampering and unauthorized access

control.title: Protect All Forms of Code from Unauthorized Access and Tampering

prop.name: label
prop.value: Protect All Forms of Code from Unauthorized Access and Tampering (PS.1)

part.name: statement
part.p: Help prevent unauthorized changes to code, both inadvertent and intentional, which could circumvent or negate the intended security characteristics of the software. For code that is not intended to be publicly accessible, this helps prevent theft of the software and may make it more difficult or time-consuming for attackers to find vulnerabilities in the software.

link.text: Securing the Source Code—Verification, Automation, Controlled Environments, Secure Authentication; Securing Materials—Automation
Vendor Software Delivery Integrity Controls, Vendor Software Development Integrity Controls

part.name: statement
part.p: Store all forms of code – including source code, executable code, and configuration-as-code – based on the principle of least privilege so that only authorized personnel, tools, services, etc. have access.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Store all source code and configuration-as-code in a code repository, and restrict access to it based on the nature of the code. For example, open-source code intended for public access may need its integrity and availability protected; other code may also need its confidentiality protected.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Use version control features of the repository to track all changes made to the code with accountability to the individual account.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Use commit signing for code repositories.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Have the code owner review and approve all changes made to the code by others.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 5:
part.p: Use code signing to help protect the integrity of executables.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 6:
part.p: Use cryptography (e.g., cryptographic hashes) to help protect file integrity.

control.title: Provide a Mechanism for Verifying Software Release Integrity

prop.name: label
prop.value: Provide a Mechanism for Verifying Software Release Integrity (PS.2)

part.name: statement
part.p: Help software acquirers ensure that the software they acquire is legitimate and has not been tampered with.

part.name: statement
part.p: Make software integrity verification information available to software acquirers.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Post cryptographic hashes for release files on a well-secured website.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Use an established certificate authority for code signing so that consumers’ operating systems or other tools and services can confirm the validity of signatures before use.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Periodically review the code signing processes, including certificate renewal, rotation, revocation, and protection.

control.title: Archive and Protect Each Software Release

prop.name: label
prop.value: Archive and Protect Each Software Release (PS.3)

part.name: statement
part.p: Preserve software releases in order to help identify, analyze, and eliminate vulnerabilities discovered in the software after release.

link.text: Securing Artefacts—Automation, Controlled Environments, Encryption; Securing Deployments—Verification

part.name: statement
part.p: Securely archive the necessary files and supporting data (e.g., integrity verification information, provenance data) to be retained for each software release.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Store the release files, associated images, etc. in repositories following the organization’s established policy. Allow read-only access to them by necessary personnel and no access by anyone else.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Store and protect release integrity verification information and provenance data, such as by keeping it in a separate location from the release files or by signing the data.

part.name: statement
part.p: Collect, safeguard, maintain, and share provenance data for all components of each software release (e.g., in a software bill of materials .SBOM).

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Make the provenance data available to software acquirers in accordance with the organization’s policies, preferably using standards-based formats.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Make the provenance data available to the organization’s operations and response teams to aid them in mitigating software vulnerabilities.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Protect the integrity of provenance data, and provide a way for recipients to verify provenance data integrity.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Update the provenance data every time any of the software’s components are updated.

prop.name: label
prop.value: Produce Well-Secured Software (PW)

part.name: overview
part.p: Organizations should produce well-secured software with minimal security vulnerabilities in its releases.

control.title: Design Software to Meet Security Requirements and Mitigate Security Risks

prop.name: label
prop.value: Design Software to Meet Security Requirements and Mitigate Security Risks (PW.1)

part.name: statement
part.p: Identify and evaluate the security requirements for the software; determine what security risks the software is likely to face during operation and how the software’s design and architecture should mitigate those risks; and justify any cases where risk-based analysis indicates that security requirements should be relaxed or waived. Addressing security requirements and risks during software design (secure by design) is key for improving software security and also helps improve development efficiency.

link.text: Tasks Requiring the Help of Security Experts 3

part.name: statement
part.p: Use forms of risk modeling – such as threat modeling, attack modeling, or attack surface mapping – to help assess the security risk for the software.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Train the development team (security champions, in particular) or collaborate with a risk modeling expert to create models and analyze how to use a risk-based approach to communicate the risks and determine how to address them, including implementing mitigations.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Perform more rigorous assessments for high-risk areas, such as protecting sensitive data and safeguarding identification, authentication, and access control, including credential management.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Review vulnerability reports and statistics for previous software to inform the security risk assessment.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Use data classification methods to identify and characterize each type of data that the software will interact with.

part.name: statement
part.p: Track and maintain the software’s security requirements, risks, and design decisions.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Record the response to each risk, including how mitigations are to be achieved and what the rationales are for any approved exceptions to the security requirements. Add any mitigations to the software’s security requirements.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Maintain records of design decisions, risk responses, and approved exceptions that can be used for auditing and maintenance purposes throughout the rest of the software life cycle.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Periodically re-evaluate all approved exceptions to the security requirements, and implement changes as needed.

link.text: Standardize Identity and Access Management; Establish Log Requirements and Audit Practices

part.name: statement
part.p: Where appropriate, build in support for using standardized security features and services (e.g., enabling software to integrate with existing log management, identity management, access control, and vulnerability management systems) instead of creating proprietary implementations of security features and services. .Formerly PW.4.3

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Maintain one or more software repositories of modules for supporting standardized security features and services.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Determine secure configurations for modules for supporting standardized security features and services, and make these configurations available (e.g., as configuration-as-code) so developers can readily use them.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Define criteria for which security features and services must be supported by software to be developed.

control.title: Review the Software Design to Verify Compliance with Security Requirements and Risk Information

prop.name: label
prop.value: Review the Software Design to Verify Compliance with Security Requirements and Risk Information (PW.2)

part.name: statement
part.p: Help ensure that the software will meet the security requirements and satisfactorily address the identified risk information.

link.text: SM-2, SR-2, SR-5, SD-3, SD-4, SI-2

part.name: statement
part.p: Have 1) a qualified person (or people) who were not involved with the design and/or 2) automated processes instantiated in the toolchain review the software design to confirm and enforce that it meets all of the security requirements and satisfactorily addresses the identified risk information.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Review the software design to confirm that it addresses applicable security requirements.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Review the risk models created during software design to determine if they appear to adequately identify the risks.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Review the software design to confirm that it satisfactorily addresses the risks identified by the risk models.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Have the software’s designer correct failures to meet the requirements.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 5:
part.p: Change the design and/or the risk response strategy if the security requirements cannot be met.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 6:
part.p: Record the findings of design reviews to serve as artifacts (e.g., in the software specification, in the issue tracking system, in the threat model).

control.title: Reuse Existing, Well-Secured Software When Feasible Instead of Duplicating Functionality

prop.name: label
prop.value: Reuse Existing, Well-Secured Software When Feasible Instead of Duplicating Functionality (PW.4)

part.name: statement
part.p: Lower the costs of software development, expedite software development, and decrease the likelihood of introducing additional security vulnerabilities into the software by reusing software modules and services that have already had their security posture checked. This is particularly important for software that implements security functionality, such as cryptographic modules and protocols.

part.name: statement
part.p: Acquire and maintain well-secured software components (e.g., software libraries, modules, middleware, frameworks) from commercial, open-source, and other third-party developers for use by the organization’s software.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Review and evaluate third-party software components in the context of their expected use. If a component is to be used in a substantially different way in the future, perform the review and evaluation again with that new context in mind.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Determine secure configurations for software components, and make these available (e.g., as configuration-as-code) so developers can readily use the configurations.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Obtain provenance information (e.g., SBOM, source composition analysis, binary software composition analysis) for each software component, and analyze that information to better assess the risk that the component may introduce.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Establish one or more software repositories to host sanctioned and vetted open-source components.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 5:
part.p: Maintain a list of organization-approved commercial software components and component versions along with their provenance data.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 6:
part.p: Designate which components must be included in software to be developed.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 7:
part.p: Implement processes to update deployed software components to newer versions, and retain older versions of software components until all transitions from those versions have been completed successfully.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 8:
part.p: If the integrity or provenance of acquired binaries cannot be confirmed, build binaries from source code after verifying the source code’s integrity and provenance.

part.name: statement
part.p: Create and maintain well-secured software components in-house following SDLC processes to meet common internal software development needs that cannot be better met by third-party software components.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Follow organization-established security practices for secure software development when creating and maintaining the components.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Determine secure configurations for software components, and make these available (e.g., as configuration-as-code) so developers can readily use the configurations.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Maintain one or more software repositories for these components.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Designate which components must be included in software to be developed.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 5:
part.p: Implement processes to update deployed software components to newer versions, and maintain older versions of software components until all transitions from those versions have been completed successfully.

link.text: Tasks Requiring the Help of Security Experts 8
Manage Security Risk Inherent in the Use of Third-Party Components
Vendor Sourcing Integrity Controls, Peer Reviews and Security Testing

part.name: statement
part.p: Verify that acquired commercial, open-source, and all other third-party software components comply with the requirements, as defined by the organization, throughout their life cycles.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Regularly check whether there are publicly known vulnerabilities in the software modules and services that vendors have not yet fixed.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Build into the toolchain automatic detection of known vulnerabilities in software components.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Use existing results from commercial services for vetting the software modules and services.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Ensure that each software component is still actively maintained and has not reached end of life; this should include new vulnerabilities found in the software being remediated.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 5:
part.p: Determine a plan of action for each software component that is no longer being maintained or will not be available in the near future.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 6:
part.p: Confirm the integrity of software components through digital signatures or other mechanisms.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 7:
part.p: Review, analyze, and/or test code. See PW.7 and PW.8.

control.title: Create Source Code by Adhering to Secure Coding Practices

prop.name: label
prop.value: Create Source Code by Adhering to Secure Coding Practices (PW.5)

part.name: statement
part.p: Decrease the number of security vulnerabilities in the software, and reduce costs by minimizing vulnerabilities introduced during source code creation that meet or exceed organization-defined vulnerability severity criteria.

link.text: Establish Log Requirements and Audit Practices, Use Code Analysis Tools to Find Security Issues Early, Handle Data Safely, Handle Errors, Use Safe Functions Only

part.name: statement
part.p: Follow all secure coding practices that are appropriate to the development languages and environment to meet the organization’s requirements.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Validate all inputs, and validate and properly encode all outputs.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Avoid using unsafe functions and calls.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Detect errors, and handle them gracefully.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Provide logging and tracing capabilities.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 5:
part.p: Use development environments with automated features that encourage or require the use of secure coding practices with just-in-time training-in-place.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 6:
part.p: Follow procedures for manually ensuring compliance with secure coding practices when automated methods are insufficient or unavailable.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 7:
part.p: Use tools (e.g., linters, formatters) to standardize the style and formatting of the source code.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 8:
part.p: Check for other vulnerabilities that are common to the development languages and environment.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 9:
part.p: Have the developer review their own human-readable code to complement (not replace) code review performed by other people or tools. See PW.7.

control.title: Configure the Compilation, Interpreter, and Build Processes to Improve Executable Security

prop.name: label
prop.value: Configure the Compilation, Interpreter, and Build Processes to Improve Executable Security (PW.6)

part.name: statement
part.p: Decrease the number of security vulnerabilities in the software and reduce costs by eliminating vulnerabilities before testing occurs.

link.text: Use Current Compiler and Toolchain Versions and Secure Compiler Options

part.name: statement
part.p: Use compiler, interpreter, and build tools that offer features to improve executable security.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Use up-to-date versions of compiler, interpreter, and build tools.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Follow change management processes when deploying or updating compiler, interpreter, and build tools, and audit all unexpected changes to tools.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Regularly validate the authenticity and integrity of compiler, interpreter, and build tools. See PO.3.

link.text: Use Current Compiler and Toolchain Versions and Secure Compiler Options

part.name: statement
part.p: Determine which compiler, interpreter, and build tool features should be used and how each should be configured, then implement and use the approved configurations.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Enable compiler features that produce warnings for poorly secured code during the compilation process.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Implement the “clean build” concept, where all compiler warnings are treated as errors and eliminated except those determined to be false positives or irrelevant.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Perform all builds in a dedicated, highly controlled build environment.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Enable compiler features that randomize or obfuscate execution characteristics, such as memory location usage, that would otherwise be predictable and thus potentially exploitable.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 5:
part.p: Test to ensure that the features are working as expected and are not inadvertently causing any operational issues or other problems.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 6:
part.p: Continuously verify that the approved configurations are being used.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 7:
part.p: Make the approved tool configurations available as configuration-as-code so developers can readily use them.

control.title: Review and/or Analyze Human-Readable Code to Identify Vulnerabilities and Verify Compliance with Security Requirements

prop.name: label
prop.value: Review and/or Analyze Human-Readable Code to Identify Vulnerabilities and Verify Compliance with Security Requirements (PW.7)

part.name: statement
part.p: Help identify vulnerabilities so that they can be corrected before the software is released to prevent exploitation. Using automated methods lowers the effort and resources needed to detect vulnerabilities. Human-readable code includes source code, scripts, and any other form of code that an organization deems human-readable.

part.name: statement
part.p: Determine whether code review (a person looks directly at the code to find issues) and/or code analysis (tools are used to find issues in code, either in a fully automated way or in conjunction with a person) should be used, as defined by the organization.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Follow the organization’s policies or guidelines for when code review should be performed and how it should be conducted. This may include third-party code and reusable code modules written in-house.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Follow the organization’s policies or guidelines for when code analysis should be performed and how it should be conducted.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Choose code review and/or analysis methods based on the stage of the software.

link.text: Operational Security Tasks 4, 7; Tasks Requiring the Help of Security Experts 10
Use Code Analysis Tools to Find Security Issues Early, Use Static Analysis Security Testing Tools, Perform Manual Verification of Security Features/Mitigations

part.name: statement
part.p: Perform the code review and/or code analysis based on the organization’s secure coding standards, and record and triage all discovered issues and recommended remediations in the development team’s workflow or issue tracking system.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Perform peer review of code, and review any existing code review, analysis, or testing results as part of the peer review.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Use expert reviewers to check code for backdoors and other malicious content.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Use peer reviewing tools that facilitate the peer review process, and document all discussions and other feedback.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Use a static analysis tool to automatically check code for vulnerabilities and compliance with the organization’s secure coding standards with a human reviewing the issues reported by the tool and remediating them as necessary.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 5:
part.p: Use review checklists to verify that the code complies with the requirements.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 6:
part.p: Use automated tools to identify and remediate documented and verified unsafe software practices on a continuous basis as human-readable code is checked into the code repository.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 7:
part.p: Identify and document the root causes of discovered issues.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 8:
part.p: Document lessons learned from code review and analysis in a wiki that developers can access and search.

control.title: Test Executable Code to Identify Vulnerabilities and Verify Compliance with Security Requirements

prop.name: label
prop.value: Test Executable Code to Identify Vulnerabilities and Verify Compliance with Security Requirements (PW.8)

part.name: statement
part.p: Help identify vulnerabilities so that they can be corrected before the software is released in order to prevent exploitation. Using automated methods lowers the effort and resources needed to detect vulnerabilities and improves traceability and repeatability. Executable code includes binaries, directly executed bytecode and source code, and any other form of code that an organization deems executable.

part.name: statement
part.p: Determine whether executable code testing should be performed to find vulnerabilities not identified by previous reviews, analysis, or testing and, if so, which types of testing should be used.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Follow the organization’s policies or guidelines for when code testing should be performed and how it should be conducted (e.g., within a sandboxed environment). This may include third-party executable code and reusable executable code modules written in-house.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Choose testing methods based on the stage of the software.

link.text: SM-5, SM-13, SI-1, SVV-1, SVV-2, SVV-3, SVV-4, SVV-5
Operational Security Tasks 10, 11; Tasks Requiring the Help of Security Experts 4, 5, 6, 7
Perform Dynamic Analysis Security Testing, Fuzz Parsers, Network Vulnerability Scanning, Perform Automated Functional Testing of Security Features/Mitigations, Perform Penetration Testing

part.name: statement
part.p: Scope the testing, design the tests, perform the testing, and document the results, including recording and triaging all discovered issues and recommended remediations in the development team’s workflow or issue tracking system.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Perform robust functional testing of security features.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Integrate dynamic vulnerability testing into the project’s automated test suite.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Incorporate tests for previously reported vulnerabilities into the project’s test suite to ensure that errors are not reintroduced.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Take into consideration the infrastructures and technology stacks that the software will be used with in production when developing test plans.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 5:
part.p: Use fuzz testing tools to find issues with input handling.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 6:
part.p: If resources are available, use penetration testing to simulate how an attacker might attempt to compromise the software in high-risk scenarios.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 7:
part.p: Identify and record the root causes of discovered issues.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 8:
part.p: Document lessons learned from code testing in a wiki that developers can access and search.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 9:
part.p: Use source code, design records, and other resources when developing test plans.

control.title: Configure Software to Have Secure Settings by Default

prop.name: label
prop.value: Configure Software to Have Secure Settings by Default (PW.9)

part.name: statement
part.p: Help improve the security of the software at the time of installation to reduce the likelihood of the software being deployed with weak security settings, putting it at greater risk of compromise.

link.text: Tasks Requiring the Help of Security Experts 12
Vendor Software Delivery Integrity Controls, Vendor Software Development Integrity Controls

part.name: statement
part.p: Define a secure baseline by determining how to configure each setting that has an effect on security or a security-related setting so that the default settings are secure and do not weaken the security functions provided by the platform, network infrastructure, or services.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Conduct testing to ensure that the settings, including the default settings, are working as expected and are not inadvertently causing any security weaknesses, operational issues, or other problems.

link.text: Tasks Requiring the Help of Security Experts 12
Verify Secure Configurations and Use of Platform Mitigation
Vendor Software Delivery Integrity Controls, Vendor Software Development Integrity Controls

part.name: statement
part.p: Implement the default settings (or groups of default settings, if applicable), and document each setting for software administrators.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Verify that the approved configuration is in place for the software.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Document each setting’s purpose, options, default value, security relevance, potential operational impact, and relationships with other settings.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Use authoritative programmatic technical mechanisms to record how each setting can be implemented and assessed by software administrators.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Store the default configuration in a usable format and follow change control practices for modifying it (e.g., configuration-as-code).

prop.name: label
prop.value: Respond to Vulnerabilities (RV)

part.name: overview
part.p: Organizations should identify residual vulnerabilities in software releases and respond appropriately to address those vulnerabilities and prevent similar ones from occurring in the future

control.title: Identify and Confirm Vulnerabilities on an Ongoing Basis

prop.name: label
prop.value: Identify and Confirm Vulnerabilities on an Ongoing Basis (RV.1)

part.name: statement
part.p: Help ensure that vulnerabilities are identified more quickly so that they can be remediated more quickly in accordance with risk, reducing the window of opportunity for attackers.

part.name: statement
part.p: Gather information from software acquirers, users, and public sources on potential vulnerabilities in the software and third-party components that the software uses, and investigate all credible reports.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Monitor vulnerability databases , security mailing lists, and other sources of vulnerability reports through manual or automated means.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Use threat intelligence sources to better understand how vulnerabilities in general are being exploited.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Automatically review provenance and software composition data for all software components to identify any new vulnerabilities they have.

link.text: SI-1, SVV-2, SVV-3, SVV-4, DM-1, DM-2

part.name: statement
part.p: Review, analyze, and/or test the software’s code to identify or confirm the presence of previously undetected vulnerabilities.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Configure the toolchain to perform automated code analysis and testing on a regular or continuous basis for all supported releases.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: See PW.7 and PW.8.

part.name: statement
part.p: Have a policy that addresses vulnerability disclosure and remediation, and implement the roles, responsibilities, and processes needed to support that policy.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Establish a vulnerability disclosure program, and make it easy for security researchers to learn about your program and report possible vulnerabilities.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Have a Product Security Incident Response Team (PSIRT) and processes in place to handle the responses to vulnerability reports and incidents, including communications plans for all stakeholders.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Have a security response playbook to handle a generic reported vulnerability, a report of zero-days, a vulnerability being exploited in the wild, and a major ongoing incident involving multiple parties and open-source software components.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Periodically conduct exercises of the product security incident response processes.

prop.name: label
prop.value: Assess, Prioritize, and Remediate Vulnerabilities (RV.2)

part.name: statement
part.p: Help ensure that vulnerabilities are remediated in accordance with risk to reduce the window of opportunity for attackers.

link.text: Operational Security Task 1, Tasks Requiring the Help of Security Experts 10

part.name: statement
part.p: Analyze each vulnerability to gather sufficient information about risk to plan its remediation or other risk response.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Use existing issue tracking software to record each vulnerability.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Perform risk calculations for each vulnerability based on estimates of its exploitability, the potential impact if exploited, and any other relevant characteristics.

link.text: Fix the Vulnerability, Identify Mitigating Factors or Workarounds

part.name: statement
part.p: Plan and implement risk responses for vulnerabilities.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Make a risk-based decision as to whether each vulnerability will be remediated or if the risk will be addressed through other means (e.g., risk acceptance, risk transference), and prioritize any actions to be taken.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: If a permanent mitigation for a vulnerability is not yet available, determine how the vulnerability can be temporarily mitigated until the permanent solution is available, and add that temporary remediation to the plan.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Develop and release security advisories that provide the necessary information to software acquirers, including descriptions of what the vulnerabilities are, how to find instances of the vulnerable software, and how to address them (e.g., where to get patches and what the patches change in the software; what configuration settings may need to be changed; how temporary workarounds could be implemented).

part.name: example
part.title: Example 4:
part.p: Deliver remediations to acquirers via an automated and trusted delivery mechanism. A single remediation could address multiple vulnerabilities.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 5:
part.p: Update records of design decisions, risk responses, and approved exceptions as needed. See PW.1.2.

control.title: Analyze Vulnerabilities to Identify Their Root Causes

prop.name: label
prop.value: Analyze Vulnerabilities to Identify Their Root Causes (RV.3)

part.name: statement
part.p: Help reduce the frequency of vulnerabilities in the future.

part.name: statement
part.p: Analyze identified vulnerabilities to determine their root causes.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Record the root cause of discovered issues.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Record lessons learned through root cause analysis in a wiki that developers can access and search.

part.name: statement
part.p: Analyze the root causes over time to identify patterns, such as a particular secure coding practice not being followed consistently.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Record lessons learned through root cause analysis in a wiki that developers can access and search.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Add mechanisms to the toolchain to automatically detect future instances of the root cause.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 3:
part.p: Update manual processes to detect future instances of the root cause.

part.name: statement
part.p: Review the software for similar vulnerabilities to eradicate a class of vulnerabilities, and proactively fix them rather than waiting for external reports.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: See PW.7 and PW.8.

part.name: statement
part.p: Review the SDLC process, and update it if appropriate to prevent (or reduce the likelihood of) the root cause recurring in updates to the software or in new software that is created.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 1:
part.p: Record lessons learned through root cause analysis in a wiki that developers can access and search.

part.name: example
part.title: Example 2:
part.p: Plan and implement changes to the appropriate SDLC practices.
